articles.headline: As Israel Prepares for War in Gaza, Debate Is Over How and How Long
articles.snippet: The country’s new unity government agrees that Hamas must be destroyed so it can never attack Israel again, but there is little appetite for a reoccupation.
articles.abstract: The country’s new unity government agrees that Hamas must be destroyed so it can never attack Israel again, but there is little appetite for a reoccupation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel, already bombing intensively in Gaza, is gearing up for a major military operation there unlike any in the past, warning the world that for Israel, after the massacre of its citizens by Hamas on Saturday, the rules have changed.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Humanitarian Crisis in Gaza Worsens as Israel Prepares a Possible Invasion
articles.snippet: As Israel retaliates for the Hamas assault last weekend and plans a potential ground attack, its airstrikes have left Gazans without power, water and medical care.
articles.abstract: As Israel retaliates for the Hamas assault last weekend and plans a potential ground attack, its airstrikes have left Gazans without power, water and medical care.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six days of Israeli airstrikes have left more than 300,000 Palestinians in the Gaza Strip homeless, with two million residents facing critical shortages of food, water and fuel, while Israeli troops prepared on Thursday for a possible ground invasion after Hamas’s deadly weekend assault.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Hiba Yazbek

articles.headline: Across U.S., Chinese Bitcoin Mines Draw National Security Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Microsoft reported one site in Wyoming because of its proximity to a data center and nuclear missile base. Records show other cryptocurrency facilities have ties to the Chinese state.
articles.abstract: Microsoft reported one site in Wyoming because of its proximity to a data center and nuclear missile base. Records show other cryptocurrency facilities have ties to the Chinese state.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a company with Chinese origins broke ground last year on a crypto-mining operation in Cheyenne, Wyo., a team at Microsoft that assesses national security threats sounded the alarm.
articles.byline: By Gabriel J.X. Dance and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: Retailers’ Seasonal Hiring Plans Signal a Cooling Labor Market
articles.snippet: After scrambling to fill out work forces in recent years, many companies are reporting more modest goals for temporary employment.
articles.abstract: After scrambling to fill out work forces in recent years, many companies are reporting more modest goals for temporary employment.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the most important selling season for retailers approaches, job applicants may feel a chill.

articles.headline: Thousands Flee Northern Gaza as Israeli Evacuation Order Stirs Panic
articles.snippet: Some residents fear a start of another permanent displacement. Gaza authorities said at least 70 people were killed when Israeli airstrikes hit some vehicles heading south.
articles.abstract: Some residents fear a start of another permanent displacement. Gaza authorities said at least 70 people were killed when Israeli airstrikes hit some vehicles heading south.
articles.lead_paragraph: Panic and chaos gripped the northern Gaza Strip Friday as thousands of people fled south in vehicles piled high with blankets and mattresses along two main roads after the Israeli military ordered a mass evacuation of half of the besieged coastal strip.

articles.headline: Microsoft Closes $69 Billion Activision Deal, Overcoming Regulators’ Objections
articles.snippet: The megadeal could strengthen Microsoft’s standing in the video game industry, after a year and a half of negotiations with regulators around the world.
articles.abstract: The megadeal could strengthen Microsoft’s standing in the video game industry, after a year and a half of negotiations with regulators around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Friday that it had closed its $69 billion purchase of the video game giant Activision Blizzard, overcoming significant regulatory hurdles in Britain and the United States and signaling that the tech industry’s giants are still free to use their cash hoards to get even bigger.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and David McCabe

articles.headline: How Microsoft Turned the Tide in Its Regulatory Fight Over Activision
articles.snippet: The company found a way to placate three of the most powerful regulatory bodies in the world, along with a federal judge in San Francisco.
articles.abstract: The company found a way to placate three of the most powerful regulatory bodies in the world, along with a federal judge in San Francisco.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first call that Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, made in early 2022 after his company announced a $69 billion deal to buy the video game publisher Activision Blizzard was to Kenichiro Yoshida, the chief executive of Sony.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise, Kellen Browning and David McCabe

articles.headline: The Upshot of Microsoft’s Activision Deal: Big Tech Can Get Even Bigger
articles.snippet: With the completion of the blockbuster acquisition, the notion that tech giants can grow through “vertical transactions” remains intact.
articles.abstract: With the completion of the blockbuster acquisition, the notion that tech giants can grow through “vertical transactions” remains intact.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden’s top antitrust officials have used novel arguments over the past few years to stop tech giants and other large companies from making deals, a strategy that has had mixed success.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and David McCabe
